case_name: Trustees of Gordhandas Govindram Family Trust v. Commissioner of Wealth Tax

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 2382-2383 of 1969 were filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 2382- 2383 of 1969. Appeals by certificate from the judgment

facts.text: Appeals arise by certificate from Bombay High Court judgment and order dated 14th and 15th February 1968 in Wealth Tax Reference No. 1.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals by certificate from the judgment and order dated 14th and 15th February 1968 of the Bombay High Court in Wealth Tax Reference No. 1.

facts.text: Appeals relate to Wealth Tax assessment of the appellant assessee for assessment years 1957-58 and 1958-59 with valuation dates December 31, 1956 and December 31, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Thest appeals relate to the Wealth Tax assessment of the appellant assessee for the assessment years 1957-58 and 1958-59, the relevant valuation date being December 31, 1956 and December 31, 1957.

facts.text: Reference made under section 27 of the Wealth Tax Act, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: They arise from a reference under s. 27 1  of the Wealth Tax Act, 1957  To be hereinafter referred to as the Act .

facts.text: Two questions of law referred to the High Court: (1) Whether trustees constitute an assessable unit under Wealth-tax Act? (2) Whether property held under trust dated 11-6-1941 is for public charitable or religious purpose under Sec. 5(1)(i).

anchor.surface_text: The two questions of law referred to the High Court are Whether on a true companystruction of the indenture of trust dated 11-6-1941 the trustees of the Trust companystitute an assessable unit under the provisions of the Wealth-tax Act ? Whether the property held by the trustees under the indenture of trust dated 11-6-1941 is held for any public purpose of a charitable or religious nature in India within the meaning of Sec. 5   1    1  of the Wealth- tax Act ?

facts.text: Bombay High Court answered both questions in favour of the Department and against the assessees.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has answered both these questions in favour of the Department and against the assessees. Hence these appeals.

facts.text: Govindram Gordhandas Seksaria, Ramnath Gordhandas Seksaria, Makhanlal Gordhandas Seksaria and Bholaram Gordhandas Seksaria constituted a Trust on June 11, 1941.

anchor.surface_text: The facts of this case lie within a narrow companypass. Govindram Gordhandas Seksaria, Ramnath Gordhandas Seksaria, Makhanlal Gordhandas Seksaria and Bholaram Gordhandas Seksaria companystituted a Trust on June 11, 1941 in respect of a sum of Rs. 1 1 lacs  Rupees eleven lacs .

facts.text: Trust created in respect of a sum of Rs. 11 lacs.

anchor.surface_text: in respect of a sum of Rs. 1 1 lacs  Rupees eleven lacs . That Trust was known as Gordhandas Govindram Family Trust.

facts.text: Trust known as Gordhandas Govindram Family Trust.

anchor.surface_text: That Trust was known as Gordhandas Govindram Family Trust. Clause  2  of the Trust deed says that it was created for giving help or relief to such poor Vaishaya Hindoos or other Hindoos as the trustees may companysider deserving 1052 of help

facts.text: Clause 2 of Trust deed: created for giving help or relief to poor Vaishaya Hindoos or other Hindoos as trustees consider deserving.

anchor.surface_text: Clause  2  of the Trust deed says that it was created for giving help or relief to such poor Vaishaya Hindoos or other Hindoos as the trustees may companysider deserving 1052 of help in the manner and to the extent hereinafter specified and subjects to the companyditions and directions stated in the next following clauses and or for the charitable object or objects hereinafter mentioned.

facts.text: Clause 3(a): Poor Vaishaya Hindoos who are members of Seksaria families preferred to poor Vaishaya Hindoos of Navalgadh.

anchor.surface_text: Clause  3   a  of the Trust deed provides that the companyditions and directions to be observed and followed by the Trustees in the execution of the Trusts herein declared as follows Poor Vaishaya Hindoos who are members of Sek- saria families shall be preferred to poor Vaishaya Hindoos of Navalgadh number belonging to that family.

facts.text: Sub-clauses b to q provide for payment of maintenance and marriage expenses of poor male or female descendants of Seksaria family.

anchor.surface_text: Sub-clauses  b  to  q  provide for the payment of maintenance and marriage expenses of the poor male or female descendants of Seksaria family.

facts.text: Sub-clause r: Rs. 5 per month for maintenance of poor male Vaishaya Hindoo.

anchor.surface_text: We shall number set out sub-clauses  r  to  u  of clause  3 . They read - Rs. 5/-  Rupees five  per month may be paid as and by way of maintenance of any poor male Vaishaya Hindoo who may be deserving of help.

facts.text: Sub-clause s: Rs. 5 per month for maintenance of poor unmarried female Vaishaya Hindoo or widow.

anchor.surface_text: Rs., 5/-  Rupees five  per month may be paid as and by way of maintain to any poor unmarried female Vaishaya Hindoo or a poor Vaishaya Hindoo or a poor Vaishaya Hindoo widow who may be deserving of help.

facts.text: Sub-clause t/u: Rs. 500 for marriage expenses of poor female Vaishaya Hindoo.

anchor.surface_text: Rs. 500/-  Rupees five hundred  may be expended or given for the purpose of meeting the expenses of marriage of any poor female Vaishaya Hindoo who may be deserving of help. Rs. 500/-  Rupees five hundred  may be expended or given for the purpose of meeting the expenses of marriage of any poor female Vaishaya Hindoo who may be deserving of help.

facts.text: If income insufficient, earlier sub-clauses prioritized over later.

anchor.surface_text: The deed further provides - If the income of the Trust Estate is number sufficient to carry out the charities specified in sub-clauses  a  to  u  above the charity specified in an earlier sub-clause shall be given priority over a charity specified in a later subclause.

facts.text: Charity primarily for benefit of members of Seksaria family.

anchor.surface_text: From the above,, it is clear that charity provided was primarily for the benefit of the members of the family of Seksaria, numberdoubt including both male and female descendants.

facts.text: Amounts for maintenance and marriage of poor Seksaria family members take substantial part of trust income.

anchor.surface_text: It is also clear from the deed that the amounts provided for the payment of maintenance and marriage expenses for the poor members of the Seksaria family is bound to take away a substantial part of the income of the trust, if number the whole of it.

facts.text: Trust name Gordhandas Govindram Family Trust indicates primary benefit for family of Gordhandas Govindram.

anchor.surface_text: As mentioned earlier, the Trust is known as Gordhandas Govindram Family Trust. That is a clear pointer. That shows that the Trust was primarily intended for the benefit of the family of Gordhandas Govindram.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds trustees constitute an assessable unit under Wealth-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: We, accordingly, agrees with the High Court and hold that the trustees of the trust, with which we are companycerned in these appeals, companystitute an assessable unit under the provisions of the Act.

facts.text: Trust is private, not for public charitable purpose, primarily for family benefit.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, it is number possible to hold that the Trust in question is a Trust for any public purpose. It is clearly a private Trust.

facts.text: Bombay High Court in prior case held trust not for charitable purpose under Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: The character of the Trust in question came to be companysidered by the Bombay High Court in Trustees of Gordhandas Govindram Family Charity Trust v. Commissioner of Income-tax  Central . Bombay,  3  under sec. 4  3   1  of the Indian Income-tax Act.

arguments.claim: The Wealth-tax Act does not provide for levy of any tax on Trusts

anchor.surface_text: It was contended before the High Court that the Wealth-tax Act does number provide for levy of any tax on Trusts. As seen earlier, this contention did number find, favour with the High Court. But that contention was repeated before this Court.

arguments.court_reasoning: No merit; s.3 applies to trustees as 'individual' including plural per General Clauses Act, confirmed by s.5(1)(i) and s.21

arguments.claim: Trustees cannot be considered as individual, HUF or company; should be association of persons but not assessable under Act

anchor.surface_text: It was urged that unlike the charging section in the income- tax Act, the charging section in the Act does number provide for the levy of tax on association of persons. It merely provides for assessing an individual or Hindu undivided family or a companypany, Trustees cannot be companysidered either individual or as Hindu Un-

arguments.court_reasoning: Trustees fall within 'individual' per s.3 read with General Clauses Act; context supports inclusion

arguments.claim: There is a lacuna in the charging section despite s.5(1)(i) and s.21 assuming trust property taxable

anchor.surface_text: It was conceded at the hearing that sec. 5  1   i  as well as s. 21 proceed on the basis that a Trust property is also liable to be taxed under the Act. But what was urged before us was that there is a lacunae in the charging section and, therefore, the trustees of a Trust cannot be taxed under the Act.

arguments.court_reasoning: No lacuna; s.3 covers trustees as individual

arguments.claim: Section 3 charges tax on every individual including trustees as per General Clauses Act definition unless context otherwise

anchor.surface_text: Sec. 3 of the Act does bring within its scope an individual which expression in view of the Central General Clauses Act includes individuals as well, unless the companytext otherwise indicates.

arguments.claim: 'Individual' wide enough to cover trustees as in Sodra Devi case

Sodr Devi, 2  this Court observed - The word assessee is wide enough to companyer number only an individual but also a Hindu undivided family, companypany and local authority and every firm and other association of persons

anchor.surface_text: In Subashini Karuri and Another v. Wealth-tax Officer, Cal- cutta and Another,  1  the Calcutta High Court opened that the joint trustees companyld be assessed as individuals under the Act. A similar view was taken by the Bombay High Court in Abhay L. Khatau and Others v. Commissioner of Wealth-tax, Bombay city II.

arguments.claim: Trust not for public charitable purpose; primarily for family benefit evident from deed, name, priority to Seksaria family members taking substantial income

anchor.surface_text: Now, let us turn to the other question viz. whether the trust in question can be companysidered as a trust created for public purpose of a charitable or religious nature. As seen earlier, the trust in question was created primarily for the benefit of the members of the family of Gordhandas Govindram Seksaria.

Kripashankar, Sodra Devi, Expenditure-tax case, Subashini Karuri, Abhay L. Khatau

holdings.text: Sec. 3 of the Act does bring within its scope an individual which expression in view of the Central General Clauses Act includes individuals as well, unless the context otherwise indicates

anchor.surface_text: The character of the Trust in question came to be considered by the Bombay High Court in Trustees of Gordhandas Govindram Family Charity Trust v. Commissioner of Income-tax Central . Bombay,  3  under sec. 4  3   1  of the Indian Income-tax Act. After examining the I various provisions, the High Court opined that it was number a trust  1  46 I.T.R. 953.  2  57 I.T.R. 202.  3  21 IT.R. 231 at 237. 1056 for charitable purpose within the meaning of Indian Income-tax Act, 1922. It was held that the primary purpose of the settlor was to benefit the members of his family and remotely and indirectly to benefit the general public. We agree with that conclusion.
